extendedMetadata.name: Objective
extendedMetadata.value: LO: 2.2: How did differences in religion affect the founding of the New England colonies?

subject: US History
metadata.bookAuthor: H. W. Brands; T. H. Breen; R. Hal Williams; Ariela J. Gros
metadata.title: FA Analyze 02 01

config.question: The “Great Migration” would not have occurred without __________.

choices.content: the failure of the Jamestown colony
the formation of the Mayflower Compact
the decimation of Plymouth by disease
the failure of Puritan movements in England

answer_3.response: Consider This: The “Great Migration” involved the movement of more than 16,000 men and women. Historians know a lot about the background of these settlers. Many of them originated in an area northeast of London called East Anglia, where Puritan ideas had taken deep root. London, Kent, and the West Country also contributed to the stream of emigrants. In some instances, entire villages were reestablished across the Atlantic. See L.O. 2.2 How did differences in religion affect the founding of the New England colonies?
